image.altText: Nicole Manison and Natasha Fyles stand side-by-side in front of a number of media microphones

items.synopsis: The government says all recommendations from a 2018 inquiry into fracking have been met, and oil and gas companies will be able to start applying to frack in the Beetaloo Basin.

title.children: Fracking in the Beetaloo Basin can go ahead, NT government announces

image.altText: A close-up of the blue and red lights on the top of a police car, unlit.

items.synopsis: Police say the alleged victim was taken to hospital and remains in a critical condition.

title.children: International student in critical condition after assault during home invasion in Darwin

image.altText: A young white woman with short blonde hair sitting in a bedroom

items.synopsis: Young Australians and social services advocates are dismayed the federal budget looks set to include a modest boost to the JobSeeker payment, but only for those over 55.

title.children: Anger over modest JobSeeker boost for over 55s while younger, Youth Allowance recipients look set to miss out

image.altText: An ibis bird perches next to the Reserve Bank of Australia headquarters in central Sydney, Australia February 6, 2018.

items.synopsis: Here's the bottom line for millions of Australians: This is now the 11th rate hike since last May and many of us are already under considerable strain. The hard numbers back this up​​​​​​, writes David Taylor.

title.children: A 'consumer recession' is barrelling towards us — and the RBA won't flinch

image.altText: a gas flare in front of an exploration well.

items.synopsis: The NT government is poised to make a final decision on whether it will green-light fracking in the Beetaloo Basin, but nearly 100 scientists have called for a fracking ban in the region, saying the costs to the community could be "enormous".

title.children: 'The end of the line': Scientists send open letter urging NT government to abandon fracking plans

image.altText: A woman in a red shirt sits among racks of clothes. She looks sad

items.synopsis: Darlene Chin was meant to be celebrating her 30th year in business in the Northern Territory capital. Instead, she's been left shaken after a ram raid shattered her shopfront.

title.children: Despite a 'senseless' ram raid on her Darwin store, Darlene won't leave town. But data suggests she's an exception

image.altText: A police woman places yellow tape across a street

items.synopsis: The ABC understands a person has been shot dead during a "high-risk incident" in regional South Australia, where two police officers were stabbed.

title.children: Two police officers stabbed in regional SA, ABC understands person shot dead

image.altText: CATL chief scientist Wu Kai

items.synopsis: The world's largest battery maker says its new battery could power electric aircraft or propel electric vehicles beyond 1,000km on a single charge.

title.children: Could this new battery spell the end for EV range anxiety?

image.altText: Smoke and flame rise from a burning fuel tank in Sevastopol, Crimea.

items.synopsis: An explosive device derails a Russian freight train in a region bordering Ukraine for a second straight day ahead of an expected counteroffensive by Kyiv.

title.children: Second Russian train hit by explosive near Ukraine border in series of attacks

image.altText: A woman with long blond hair smiles.

items.synopsis: Canberra make-up artist Mel White had just reached her lifelong goal with a job working on the Baz Luhrmann film Elvis when her life drastically changed.

title.children: Mel had just wrapped as a make-up artist on a Hollywood blockbuster — soon after, she could barely walk

image.altText: Flowers and tributes on the side of the road

items.synopsis: A fourth woman injured in the crash remains in hospital in a serious condition, as authorities offer support services across the community.

title.children: 13yo charged over Qld triple-fatal car crash faces Children's Court

image.altText: A group of young women singing on the side of a boat.

items.synopsis: Decades before any climate change blockades, young people put their bodies on the line to save a wild river. Here's what we can learn from them today.

title.children: 'We were living on the edge of nothing': The activists who risked it all to defend a wild river

image.altText: Six water pipes run downhill towards a dam.

items.synopsis: Just three months into the role, Snowy Hydro's new boss admits the pumped-hydro battery project is facing up to another two years of delays.

title.children: Snowy Hydro 2.0 project faces further two years of delays

image.altText: Smoke rises from buildings in the city of Khartoum, where a man can be seen in the foreground walking on the ground.

items.synopsis: A Royal Australian Air Force plane evacuates 36 Australians and their family members from Sudan in an overnight mission.

title.children: RAAF rescue mission evacuates 36 Australians and their family members from Sudan

image.altText: Afaf Sinada, dressed in a white headscarf, holds a hand to her face, with a deeply sorrowful expression.

items.synopsis: Sudanese visitors are scrambling to find a way to remain in Australia, as violence and unrest in Sudan cuts off their path back home.

title.children: How civil unrest in Sudan has turned a family holiday into a potential five-year visa wait

image.altText: A man in a pink shirt.

items.synopsis: The bodies of more than 100 people have been found in the Shakahola forest since police began searching the area in east Kenya.

title.children: What we know about the Kenyan cult case and the pastors allegedly behind it

image.altText: Man wearing sunnies and baseball cap holding a fish.

items.synopsis: Formal identification process begins after human remains found inside a 4.1-metre crocodile, one of two shot by rangers near where a 65-year-old publican went missing at the weekend. Wildlife officers believe both animals were involved.

title.children: Grim find confirms two crocs involved in fisherman's death

image.altText: Players on a football field.

items.synopsis: AFL boss Gill McLachlan was cryptic when he departed Melbourne for Hobart this morning, but Tasmania's premier is already celebrating "decades of fighting" for a state AFL team coming to an end.

title.children: Excitement as AFL boss flies to Hobart for team announcement

schema.headline: Tasmania's AFL licence to be officially announced as premier hails 'decades of fighting' coming to an end

liveBlogUpdate.headline: St Kilda's Ross Lyon flags 'challenges'
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Ahead of the presser starting, Ross Lyon has already been chatting to journos this morning talking up "traditional football". "It's been a long-drawn out process, I suppose, but a considered one. I'm a football traditionalist. They [Tasmania] are a traditional football state. "We want to be a truly national competition. It means some challenges going forward for clubs," he says. "We're already strategising … to try and understand what the ramifications are, because someone's gotta pay the ferryman."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Go the Apples?
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: What's the team going to be called? There are a few suggestions kicking around: Islanders, Tassie Apples, Mountaineers, Devils. What do you think the Tasmanian team should be named?

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Long and winding road to here
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Tasmanians have wanted this team for decades. The first serious bid was 1994 and several failed bids followed. Announcing $240m of federal stadium funding on Saturday, Prime Minister Anthony Albanese said it "wasn't an Australian Football League if it leaves off the south island". But, in 2023, it's finally in the bag. It's expected to be 2027 before the team runs onto an AFL ground, initally playing games at Hobart's Bellerive Oval and Launceston's York Park .

liveBlogUpdate.headline: A Tasmanian team is born
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Hello and thanks for joining us. Ros Lehman and I have strapped on the boots and are ready to bring you this much-anticipated media conference announcing Tassie's official entry to the AFL. We expect to hear from AFL chief executive Gillon McLachlan, the Premier of Tasmania Jeremy Rockliff, Acting Prime Minister Richard Marles, as well as Richmond's Jack Riewoldt, North Melbourne's Nicole Bresnehan, triple Premiership player with Brisbane Lions Alastair Lynch and chair of the Tasmania Taskforce Brett Godfrey .

liveBlogStreamPrepared.name: Tasmania's AFL licence to be officially announced as premier hails 'decades of fighting' coming to an end

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext:
I anticipate about 300 stadium questions that won't be answered in any meaningful way. Should be fun!
Let's go the Tassie WB Devils! - Damo.

"It's been a long-drawn out process, I suppose, but a considered one. I'm a football traditionalist. They [Tasmania] are a traditional football state. "We want to be a truly national competition. It means some challenges going forward for clubs," he says. "We're already strategising … to try and understand what the ramifications are, because someone's gotta pay the ferryman."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Tell them to shove the AFL Team and the stadium up their backside. Whatever a waste of money when we need better health care better roads and more teachers.  - Nev .

children.content: Tell them to shove the AFL Team and the stadium up their backside. Whatever a waste of money when we need better health care better roads and more teachers.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: So we don't have enough money in the state to save the mental health inpatient hospital, but we have enough to build a stadium so that we can get our own AFL team. Lovely.  - Maslow.

children.content: So we don't have enough money in the state to save the mental health inpatient hospital, but we have enough to build a stadium so that we can get our own AFL team. Lovely.

image.altText: A composite of Queen Mary's crown and Queen Consort Camila.

items.synopsis: The Queen Consort's crown will swap out the controversial Kohinoor diamond and instead feature three other diamonds from the royal collection: the Cullinan III, IV and V, but these could be just as contentious.

title.children: Camilla took a controversial jewel off her crown. But its replacement has raised some eyebrows

image.altText: A stadium during a rugby league match

items.synopsis: NRL teams getting points for the bye has thrown the competition ladder into chaos. But why does it happen in the first place?

title.children: NRL teams still get two competition points for the bye due to this old and outdated tradition

image.altText: A posted wanted sign for a mass shooting suspect is seen by the roadside.

title.children: Suspected gunman caught in Texas four days after five people killed, including child

title.children: Nick Cave confirms he's 'not a monarchist' as he defends plan to attend coronation

image.altText: Gianni Infantino holds up a finger

items.synopsis: Having undervalued the women's game for so long, FIFA is now complaining that other organisations are, too. The irony is stark, writes Samantha Lewis.

title.children: Why FIFA is to blame for a potential Women's World Cup broadcast blackout

image.altText: Image of public bathroom. On one side dirty needles and bloody tissues on the floor on right needles on sink

items.synopsis: The floor was littered with used needles, but disability access advocates say a special key may be the solution to stopping vandals and drug users from littering bathrooms.

title.children: 6yo's run-in with dirty needles in accessible toilet sparks divisive debate on disability master key access
